awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Artificial Intelligence (AI)-assisted sustainable cement manufacturing technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a computational technology for building sustainable cement construction materials.  Cement manufacturing is one of the largest and most energy and carbon-intensive industries in the world. Reducing the energy costs and the carbon footprint of cement manufacturing may offer an opportunity to improve profitability and lower environmental impact. The proposed technology may be used by research scientists and decision makers to improve performance, sustainability, and economic value of the cementitious materials and manufacturing process.  The pathway for improving the sustainability of cementitious material manufacturing and product quality is low energy input, leading to a low carbon footprint and high economic benefits. End users include product manufacturers, cement and concrete admixture companies, codes and standards committees, and public decision-makers. This technology may be important to ensuring development is planned and conducted in a manner that is consistent with an accurate view of sustainability.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of data-driven physical and chemical modeling for cement materials and manufacturing process. The proposed technology integrates the advanced reaction process simulation, cementitious materials modeling, and artificial intelligence optimization and machine learning algorithms. The technology has the potential to effectively provide optimal operational conditions for low-cost, low-carbon, high-performance cementitious materials and a manufacturing industry based on user-defined criteria. In addition, a user-friendly platform is a part of the proposed design to facilitate the use of artificial intelligence technology in improving the sustainability of construction materials industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Through the completion of the NSF I-Corps project, the team established connections with stakeholders from cement and concrete industry, national labs, academia, organization and government, understand the current decarbonization and energy efficiency practices and needs for sustainable cement manufacturing. The team showcase their technology with an available computational toolbox for optimizing energy consumption, carbon footprint, material properties, and cost at the American Concrete Institute conventions, American Society of Civil Engineers conferences, labs of U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, cement plants and material labs cement and concrete industry, and Purdue construction career fairs. The team received valuable insights from industry stakeholders on current practices and shortages to reduce carbon footprint in cement production. According to the discussion, the team identified the stakeholders’ needs for cost, energy, and carbon reduction, and revised the user-defined computational toolbox according to the needs and generated one journal paper and one technical patent. Long-term collaborations were with the industrial partners for future implementation of the toolbox in practice. The results of this project, particularly the accurate and robust estimate of clinker production and corresponding material properties and environmental impact, will significantly improve the material quality and environmental sustainability for civil and construction industry. The AI-driven sustainable manufacturing framework would be useful to manufacture a range of materials of cement and beyond (metals, other ceramics, cermets, etc.). The attached images show the outreach activities conducted by the team including site visit to concrete materials labs and plants at Ozinga in Chicago and U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Pittsburgh District, and K-12 educational activities such as filming K-12 STEM education videos about sustainable and resilient infrastructure materials posted on YouTube as part of Purdue’s Superheroes of Science Series.
